"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." Summarized chunk:
Congress finds that Jerry Lewis, a talented comedian from New Jersey, began his career in local nightclubs before forming a successful partnership with Dean Martin, leading to 16 major motion pictures. Jerry Lewis, a successful performer in show business, received worldwide acclaim for his unique ability in comedy and drama. He is considered among the elite in the history of comedy and has been an active champion for the Muscular Dystrophy Association since the early 1950s, starting the annual "Jerry Lewis MDA Labor Day Telethon" in 1966 to benefit those affected by muscular dystrophy. Jerry Lewis, a renowned performer, has been a dedicated advocate for the Muscular Dystrophy Association for over 40 years. His annual telethon raises millions of dollars and he has received awards for his service, including a Nobel Peace Prize nomination. Lewis's commitment to helping those affected by neuromuscular diseases is driven by his belief in doing good and showing kindness to others. Jerry Lewis received numerous awards for his humanitarian efforts, including the National Association of Television Program Executives Award of the Year and induction into the French Legion of Honor. He was also honored with the American Medical Association Lifetime Achievement Award and the Governor's Award from the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. In 1976, the United States Senate unanimously adopted a resolution appreciating his philanthropic endeavors. Jerry Lewis, known for his philanthropic efforts, led a delegation to testify before the US Senate in 2001, resulting in the passage of the MD-Care Act. He has been National Chairman of the Muscular Dystrophy Association for over 5 decades and is deserving of the Congressional Gold Medal. Jerry Lewis is to receive a Congressional Gold Medal for his outstanding service to the Nation, with the design and striking of the medal to be determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, provisions for duplicate medals are included in the legislation. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates of the gold medal at a price covering costs. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items. Authorization of appropriations and proceeds from sales are also included. SEC. 5. Authorization of appropriations from the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund for the cost of medals struck under this Act. Proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited into the same fund.
